top_categories.workout_context: Paris to Ancaster's Rail trail, Farm lanes forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 62 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Paris to Ancaster's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before April.
62 miles on multi-surface chaos—rail trails to mud chutes in burns energy faster than the distance suggests. Train the fade resistance now.
When someone attacks on multi-surface chaos—rail trails to mud chutes in, you have 10 seconds to respond or you're off the back. This builds that response.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Paris to Ancaster, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
65ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on multi-surface chaos—rail trails to mud chutes in. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
At Paris to Ancaster, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Paris to Ancaster. Train it until it feels boring.
Base fitness for Paris to Ancaster. Without this, the hard workouts break you down instead of building you up.
Smooth pedaling at 62 miles saves muscle. Bad technique at mile 10 is invisible. At mile 80 it's a cramp.
Varied gradients on multi-surface chaos—rail trails to mud chutes in demand climbing versatility. Sit the shallow stuff, stand the steep stuff, switch without thinking.

race_overlay.heat: April in Paris to Ancaster, Ontario, Canada can bring heat. Complete 3–4 heat exposure sessions in the final 2 weeks before Paris to Ancaster. Increase sodium intake 48 hours before race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Paris to Ancaster’s 62 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Paris to Ancaster demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride multi-surface chaos—rail trails to mud chutes in one race at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: rail trail, farm lanes, mud chutes. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 62 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, Race Simulation, and Durability to prepare you for 62 miles of multi-surface chaos—rail trails to mud chutes in one race in Paris to Ancaster, Ontario, Canada.
